name: A1 : Sentences

questions.question: I'm off for two weeks at August.
options: ~I'm off for two weeks at August.
=I'm off for two weeks in August.
~I'm off for two weeks on August.
~I'm off for two weeks between August.
questions.examples:
My friend at work is from Japan.
The factory workers have been on strike since January.
Between you and me, I don't think he's a very good teacher.

questions.question: The factory workers have been on strike since January.
options: =The factory workers have been on strike since January.
~The factory workers have been in strike since January.
~The factory workers have been about strike since January.
~The factory workers have been through strike since January.

questions.question: During our visit to Japan, we saw a lot of interesting places.

questions.question: I spent a quiet afternoon at home reading to myself.
options: ~I spent an quiet afternoon at home reading to myself.

~I spent a quiet afternoon at home reading to himself.

questions.question: Tomorrow we will be going to Tulasis party.
options: ~Tomorrow we will be going to Tulasis party.
~Tomorrow we will be going, to Tulasi’s party.
=Tomorrow, we will be going to Tulasi’s party.
~Tomorrow we will be going to Tulasi’s party.
questions.examples:
In similar usage, we can also see the examples given below for the placement of the comma.
Why, I can't believe this!
No, you can't have a dollar.

For a similar use of the apostrophe, have a look at the examples given below:
a woman's hat
the boss's wife
Mrs. Chang's house

questions.question: I am going to buy three apple.
options: ~I am going to buy three apple.
~I going to buy three apples.
~I go to buy three apples.
=I am going to buy three apples.
questions.examples:
A similar example in the usage of the Simple Future Tense can be seen in the sentence given below:
I am leaving later today.
He is going to faint.

questions.question: In five minutes I will had been working for ten hours.
options: ~In five minutes I will had been working for ten hours.
=In five minutes, I will have been working for ten hours.
~In five minutes I will be working for ten hours.
~In five minutes, I had been working for ten hours.
questions.examples:
Some more examples which use the “will have been” + present form of the verb are:
Will you have been waiting for more than two hours when her plane finally arrives?
They will have been talking for over an hour by the time Thomas arrives.

questions.question: I will like more tea she said to the server.
options: ~I will like more tea she said to the server.
~“I will like more tea,” she said to the server.
=“I would like more tea,” she said to the server.
~“I like more tea,” she said to the server.
questions.examples:
Some other examples in similar form are:
When I was young I would do my homework every evening.
In the summer we would always go camping.

questions.question: If he try hard enuf, Bill can become an actor some day.
options: ~If he try hard enuf, Bill can become an actor some day.
=If he tries hard enough, Bill could become an actor some day.
~If he tries hard enough, Bill can become an actor some day.
~If he try hard enough, Bill can become an actor some day.
questions.examples:
Some more examples which are similar are:
If we don’t hurry we could be late.
If you are not careful, you could lose your way in the dark.

questions.question: Today is Monday May four 2015.
options: ~Today is Monday May four 2015.
~Today is Monday May fourth 2015.
~Today is Monday, May fourth 2015.
=Today is Monday, May fourth, 2015.
questions.examples:
Some similar examples of this rule can be seen in the sentences given below:
The store closed its doors for good on Wednesday, October 15, 1958.
The meeting scheduled for July 10, 2011, was cancelled due to a hurricane watch.

questions.question: I simply cannot wait to get there!
options: =I simply cannot wait to get there!
~I simply cannot wait to getting there!
~I cannot simply wait to get there!
~I cannot wait simply to get there!
questions.examples:
Some more examples which show us the order of Subject-verb-object (and other parts of speech) in a sentence can be seen here:
We always have to wait a long time for the bus.
He sometimes plays golf on Sundays.

questions.question: Me and my friend are gonna go to the beach next weekend.
options: ~Me and my friend are gonna go to the beach next weekend.
=My friend and I are going to go to the beach next weekend.
~My friend and me are going to the beach next weekend.
~My friend are gonna to the beach next weekend.
questions.examples:
Some more examples showing the order of I / me in a sentence are given here:
Janaki and I walked down the road.
If you have a problem, please call Rishi or me.
She gave the ball to Janaki and me.

questions.question: What he got for Diwali? she asked.
options: ~What he got for Diwali? she asked.
~“What he get for Diwali?” she asked.
=“What did he get for Diwali?” she asked.
~“What he gets for Diwali?” she asked.

Some more examples in the same form are:

questions.question: When are we going?
options: =When are we going?
~When we are going?
~When going are we?
~When we going?
questions.examples:
Some other examples of the SVO order in question sentences are:
When were you here?
Whoaskedyou?

questions.question: We going now?
options: ~We going now?
=Are we going now?
~We going are now?
~We are go now?

Some other examples of the SVO order in such question sentences are:
